questions.text: Under anaerobic metabolism which of the following substrates yields 3 molecules of ATP? ( AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glycogen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Under anaerobic conditions, glycogen yields 3 molecules of ATP per glucose unit because it enters glycolysis as glucose-6-phosphate, bypassing the initial ATP-consuming step of glycolysis.

questions.text: Enzyme defect in McArdle’s Disease?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Myophosphorylase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ McArdle's disease is Type V glycogen storage disease that occurs due to deficiency of muscle glycogen phosphorylase (Myophosphorylase) enzyme. In this disease, muscle glycogen cannot be used during exercise, so, on strenuous exercise there are muscles cramps. Also, normal or relatively low levels of lactate will be formed from muscle glycogen after exercise.

References:

  • ↳ Reference : Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 167

questions.text: In Pompe’s disease, enzyme deficiency is? ( INICET May 2023
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lysosomal acid alpha glucosidase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In individuals with Pompe's disease, the deficiency of lysosomal acid alpha glucosidase leads to the accumulation of glycogen in various tissues, particularly the muscles. This glycogen buildup affects the proper functioning of cells and tissues, causing a wide range of symptoms, primarily affecting the muscles and respiratory system.

questions.text: An infant presented to the OPD with a history of vomiting and poor feeding. Musty odor is present in the baby's sweat and urine. Guthrie test was done and it was found to be positive. All are true regarding this disease except? ( AIIMS May 2018)

options.label: B
options.text: White patch of hair due to tryptophan deficiency

questions.correct_answer: B. White patch of hair due to tryptophan deficiency
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) White patch of hair due to tryptophan deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ PKU is characterized by a deficiency in phenylalanine hydroxylase, leading to elevated phenylalanine levels and its metabolites, which cause neurological symptoms, hypopigmentation, and a musty odor. Early detection and dietary management are crucial for preventing severe mental retardation.

questions.text: An infant present with hypotonia and seizures. It was confirmed to be cerebrohepatorenal syndrome. Which of the following is accumulated in the brain in cerebrohepatorenal syndrome? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Long chain fatty acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Zellweger syndrome or Cerebrohepatorenal syndrome is due to defective oxidation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA ). Peroxisomal enzymes are produced; but their entry into peroxisome is denied. This leads to insufficient oxidation of VLCFA. Accumulation of VLCFA in CNS causes profound neurologic impairment and death in childhood.
  • ➤ Zellweger syndrome or Cerebrohepatorenal syndrome is due to defective oxidation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA
  • ➤ Accumulation of VLCFA in CNS causes profound neurologic impairment

questions.text: Why is the HCO3/H2CO3 buffer system considered the most effective in the body? (AIIMS NOV 2016)

options.label: B
options.text: Its components can be increased or decreased in the body as needed

options.label: C
options.text: Good acceptor and donor of H+ ions

options.label: D
options.text: Combination of a weak acid and weak base

questions.correct_answer: B. Its components can be increased or decreased in the body as needed
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The bicarbonate (HCO3)/carbonic acid (H2CO3) buffer system is deemed the most effective buffer in the body primarily because both its components—bicarbonate and carbon dioxide (converted to/from carbonic acid)—can be adjusted by the body's metabolic and respiratory processes. The kidneys regulate the concentration of bicarbonate in the blood by either reabsorbing or excreting it, while the lungs control the levels of carbon dioxide through respiration. This dual control allows for a highly responsive and effective system to maintain blood pH within a narrow optimal range.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. pKa near physiological pH: While the pKa of carbonic acid is close to the physiological pH, making it a good buffer, this is not the unique reason it is the best buffer. Option C. Good acceptor and donor of H+ ions: All buffers accept and donate H+ ions; this property is not unique to the bicarbonate buffer system. Option D. Combination of a weak acid and weak base: While true, the key to the bicarbonate buffer's effectiveness is its dynamic regulation by the respiratory and renal systems, not merely its composition.
  • • Option A. pKa near physiological pH: While the pKa of carbonic acid is close to the physiological pH, making it a good buffer, this is not the unique reason it is the best buffer.
  • • Option A. pKa near physiological pH:
  • • Option C. Good acceptor and donor of H+ ions: All buffers accept and donate H+ ions; this property is not unique to the bicarbonate buffer system.
  • • Option C. Good acceptor and donor of H+ ions:
  • • Option D. Combination of a weak acid and weak base: While true, the key to the bicarbonate buffer's effectiveness is its dynamic regulation by the respiratory and renal systems, not merely its composition.
  • • Option D. Combination of a weak acid and weak base:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The bicarbonate buffer system is unique in its ability to regulate pH through respiratory (CO2 control) and renal (HCO3 control) mechanisms, making it a critical component in maintaining the body's acid-base balance.

questions.text: dd-NTPs in Sanger’s Sequencing technique uses? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Termination of polymerase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dideoxy nucleotides are nucleotides in which O from 2’ and 3’ position of sugar is absent. These nucleotides, if inserted in the growing DNA chains will cause termination of polymerization as DNA polymerase will not be able to perform catalyzation of formation of Phosphodiester bond. This form the basis for a DNA sequencing technique know as Sanger DNA sequencing aka chain termination method.
  • ➤ termination of polymerization

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 439

questions.text: Vitamin K in its coenzyme form is regenerated by the enzyme? ( AIIMS Nov 2018)

questions.text: Refsum’s disease is caused by the defect of? ( INICET Nov 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Beta oxidation of branched chain fatty acid

options.label: B
options.text: Alpha oxidation of branched chain fatty acid

options.label: C
options.text: Omega oxidation of branched chain fatty acid

questions.correct_answer: B. Alpha oxidation of branched chain fatty acid
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Alpha oxidation of branched-chain fatty acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Characteristic of Peroxisomal pathways:
  • ➤ Characteristic of Peroxisomal pathways:
  • ➤ No ATP production in any of peroxisomal pathways H 2 O 2 is regularly formed which is neutralized by peroxisomal enzymes catalase & peroxidase. Two pathways which occur in peroxisomes are:
  • ➤ No ATP production in any of peroxisomal pathways
  • ➤ H 2 O 2 is regularly formed which is neutralized by peroxisomal enzymes catalase & peroxidase.
  • ➤ Two pathways which occur in peroxisomes are:
  • ➤ 1. α-Oxidation of branched chain fatty acids (BCFA)
  • ➤ 2. Oxidation of Very Long Chain Fatty Acid (VLCFA)
  • ➤ Refsum's disease: Occur due to defect in α-oxidation of BCFA in peroxisomes due to defect in phytanic acid hydroxylase. So, Phytanic acid not oxidised.
  • ➤ Refsum's disease:
  • ➤ Beta-oxidation occurs for saturated and even chain fatty acids like palmitic and stearic acid In Omega-oxidation dicarboxylic acids are formed. In MCAD deficiency there is dicarboxylic acidosis and non-ketotic hypoglycemia.
  • ➤ Beta-oxidation occurs for saturated and even chain fatty acids like palmitic and stearic acid
  • ➤ In Omega-oxidation dicarboxylic acids are formed. In MCAD deficiency there is dicarboxylic acidosis and non-ketotic hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the emergency department with generalized fatigue and mild shortness of breath. Laboratory tests reveal elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels. An LDH electrophoresis shows a flipped pattern, with LDH1 levels higher than LDH2. Which of the following clinical conditions is most commonly associated with this flipped LDH ratio?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A flipped LDH ratio, where LDH1 is greater than LDH2, is indicative of myocardial infarction (MI). Normally, LDH2 is the predominant form in the blood, while LDH1 is more abundant in the heart. During an MI, cardiac tissue damage leads to the release of LDH1 into the bloodstream, resulting in an elevated LDH1 ratio, known as the flipped pattern. This specific enzyme pattern is a hallmark of cardiac injury, particularly in the context of other cardiac markers such as troponins.
  • • Types of LDH:
  • • Types of LDH:
  • • LDH-1: Predominantly found in the heart and red blood cells.
  • • LDH-1:
  • • LDH-2: Most commonly found in the blood and lymph nodes.
  • • LDH-2:
  • • LDH-3: Found in the brain, kidney, lungs, spleen, and pancreas.
  • • LDH-3:
  • • LDH-4: Located in the liver and skeletal muscle.
  • • LDH-4:
  • • LDH-5: Also present in the liver and skeletal muscle.
  • • LDH-5:
  • • These patterns help differentiate tissue injuries based on which LDH isoenzyme levels are elevated.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Liver disease: Liver disease primarily involves elevations in LDH4 and LDH5, which are found in the liver and skeletal muscle. A flipped LDH ratio (LDH1 > LDH2) is not characteristic of liver pathology.
  • • Option A. Liver disease:
  • • Option C. Skeletal muscle injury: Skeletal muscle injuries typically result in increased levels of LDH4 and LDH5 due to their higher concentration in muscle tissues. LDH1 and LDH2 are not predominantly affected in these conditions.
  • • Option C. Skeletal muscle injury:
  • • Option D. Hemolytic anemia: Hemolytic anemia typically shows an increase in LDH2, as this isoenzyme is abundant in red blood cells. A flipped LDH ratio is not a classic finding in hemolytic anemia.
  • • Option D. Hemolytic anemia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A flipped LDH ratio, where LDH1 is higher than LDH2, indicates myocardial infarction due to the release of LDH1 from cardiac tissue into the bloodstream. Understanding the types of LDH isoenzymes—LDH-1 (heart), LDH-2 (blood), LDH-3 (brain, kidney, lungs), LDH-4, and LDH-5 (liver and skeletal muscle)—is essential for differentiating tissue injuries and diagnosing conditions like myocardial infarction, liver disease, and muscle damage accurately.

questions.text: Which modification will lead to Various short and long-acting analogs of the hormone given in the picture ?
questions.correct_answer: C. Change in 29-30 in B chain
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Change in 29-30 in B chain

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The hormone depicted in the image is insulin .
  • • insulin
  • • Insulin's primary structure consists of two polypeptide chains: the A chain (21 amino acids) and the B chain (30 amino acids).
  • • There are two interchain disulfide bonds:
  • • There are two interchain disulfide bonds:
  • • Between the 7th amino acid of the A chain and the 7th amino acid of the B chain. Between the 20th amino acid of the A chain and the 19th amino acid of the B chain. One intrachain disulfide bond exists between the 6th and 11th amino acids of the A chain.
  • • Between the 7th amino acid of the A chain and the 7th amino acid of the B chain.
  • • Between the 20th amino acid of the A chain and the 19th amino acid of the B chain. One intrachain disulfide bond exists between the 6th and 11th amino acids of the A chain.
  • • Modifications in amino acids 29-30 of the B chain result in the production of short- and long-acting insulin types, depending on the changes made
  • • Other Options Explanation:
  • • Other Options Explanation:
  • • Option A. Hydrolysis of disulphide bonds: Disrupts the structural integrity of insulin, leading to loss of biological activity.
  • • Option A. Hydrolysis of disulphide bonds:
  • • Option B. Change in 5-6 in A chain: Changing the sequence in the critical A chain can affect the folding and activity of insulin.
  • • Option B. Change in 5-6 in A chain:
  • • Option D. Change in 14-16 in A chain: Changing the sequence in the A chain can disrupt the structure and function of insulin.
  • • Option D. Change in 14-16 in A chain:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is false in a patient with advanced liver disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Oxidative decarboxylation of alpha-ketoglutarate is increased.

options.label: B
options.text: ﻿﻿﻿Increased synthesis of glutamine and glutamate from alpha-ketoglutarate

questions.correct_answer: A. Oxidative decarboxylation of alpha-ketoglutarate is increased.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Oxidative decarboxylation of alpha-ketoglutarate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Detoxification of ammonia takes place in the liver, where it is metabolised and excreted as urea (urea cycle). Due to impairment of ammonia metabolism in advanced liver disease, ammonia levels increase which withdraws α-ketoglutarate to form glutamate and glutamine.
  • ➤ This in turn results in lowered concentrations of all citric acid cycle intermediates, and hence decreased ATP synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following is deficient in a patient with features as shown below?
questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Pellagra can occur due to:
  • ➤ Pellagra can occur due to:
  • ➤ ﻿﻿ Vitamin B3 (Niacin) deficiency ﻿﻿Tryptophan deficiency: Niacin is synthetised from tryptophan Deficient synthesis: Kynureninase, an important enzyme in the pathway of tryptophan, is pyridoxal phosphate dependent. So, conversion of tryptophan to niacin is not possible in pyridoxal deficiency. Isoniazid (INH): It is an anti-tubercular drug, which inhibits pyridoxal phosphate formation. Hence, there is block in conversion of tryptophan to NAD. Hartnup disease: Tryptophan absorption from intestine is defective in this congenital disease. Moreover, tryptophan is excreted in urine in large quantities. This leads to lack of tryptophan and consequently deficiency of nicotinamide. Carcinoid syndrome: The tumor utilizes major portion of available tryptophan for synthesis of serotonin; so, tryptophan is unavailable.
  • ➤ ﻿﻿ Vitamin B3 (Niacin) deficiency
  • ➤ Vitamin B3 (Niacin) deficiency
  • ➤ ﻿﻿Tryptophan deficiency: Niacin is synthetised from tryptophan
  • ➤ ﻿﻿Tryptophan deficiency:
  • ➤ Deficient synthesis: Kynureninase, an important enzyme in the pathway of tryptophan, is pyridoxal phosphate dependent. So, conversion of tryptophan to niacin is not possible in pyridoxal deficiency.
  • ➤ Deficient synthesis:
  • ➤ Isoniazid (INH): It is an anti-tubercular drug, which inhibits pyridoxal phosphate formation. Hence, there is block in conversion of tryptophan to NAD.

  • ➤ Carcinoid syndrome: The tumor utilizes major portion of available tryptophan for synthesis of serotonin; so, tryptophan is unavailable.

questions.text: Acute inflammatory response is not seen in: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Apoptosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Apoptosis is a non-inflammatory form of programmed cell death, characterized by the maintenance of membrane integrity and the absence of an acute inflammatory response. In contrast, necrosis, necroptosis, and pyroptosis involve membrane rupture and the release of intracellular contents, leading to inflammation.
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease, 8 th edition, Pg 33-34

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought to emergency following an episode of syncope during his morning walk. His blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg. He has a history of myocardial infarction 5yrs back. His ECG is given below. Which is the most appropriate treatment for patient? ( AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) DC Cardioversion.

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient presenting with ventricular tachycardia and signs of hemodynamic instability, DC Cardioversion is the recommended treatment to quickly restore normal heart rhythm. Pharmacological treatments like amiodarone may be considered post-cardioversion for rhythm stabilization in stable patients.

questions.text: Which of the following processes does not occur in mitochondria? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Fatty acid synthesis primarily occurs in the cytosol of cells, not in mitochondria. This process involves a series of enzymatic reactions that build fatty acids from acetyl-CoA and malonyl-CoA through a repeating series of steps involving condensation, reduction, and dehydration. The enzyme complex responsible for this, known as Fatty Acid Synthase (FAS), is located in the cytosol, utilizing NADPH as a reducing agent and producing palmitate.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • a. Beta-oxidation of fatty acids: This process does indeed occur in mitochondria, where fatty acids are broken down to acetyl-CoA. b. DNA synthesis: While mitochondria contain their own DNA and can replicate it, the major DNA synthesis activities, particularly of nuclear DNA, occur in the nucleus. d. Protein synthesis: Some mitochondrial proteins are synthesized within the mitochondria themselves from their own DNA.
  • • a. Beta-oxidation of fatty acids: This process does indeed occur in mitochondria, where fatty acids are broken down to acetyl-CoA.
  • • a. Beta-oxidation of fatty acids:
  • • b. DNA synthesis: While mitochondria contain their own DNA and can replicate it, the major DNA synthesis activities, particularly of nuclear DNA, occur in the nucleus.
  • • b. DNA synthesis:
  • • d. Protein synthesis: Some mitochondrial proteins are synthesized within the mitochondria themselves from their own DNA.
  • • d. Protein synthesis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fatty acid synthesis is an anabolic process occurring in the cytosol, contrasting with beta-oxidation, a catabolic process occurring in mitochondria.

questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Whole Bowel Irrigation

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl with a known history of Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus (T1DM) is brought to the emergency room with symptoms of abdominal pain, nausea, and rapid breathing. Laboratory tests reveal elevated blood glucose, low serum bicarbonate, and high levels of ketones in her blood and urine. What is the primary reason ketosis is common in patients with Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus?

options.label: B
options.text: Increased mobilization of fat from adipose tissue

options.label: C
options.text: Enhanced glycogen synthesis in the liver

questions.correct_answer: B. Increased mobilization of fat from adipose tissue
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus, insulin deficiency leads to decreased glucose uptake by tissues such as skeletal muscle and the heart, which rely on insulin for glucose entry. As a result, the body compensates by increasing lipolysis in adipose tissue, releasing free fatty acids into the bloodstream. These fatty acids are transported to the liver, where they undergo beta-oxidation to produce acetyl CoA. Because of insulin deficiency, oxaloacetate is preferentially used for gluconeogenesis, leading to reduced entry of acetyl CoA into the TCA cycle. This accumulation of acetyl CoA results in enhanced ketogenesis, producing ketone bodies such as acetoacetate and beta-hydroxybutyrate, which contribute to the state of ketosis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Decreased lipolysis in adipose tissue: This is incorrect as insulin deficiency in T1DM actually leads to increased lipolysis, releasing fatty acids that fuel ketogenesis.
  • • Option A. Decreased lipolysis in adipose tissue:
  • • Option C. Enhanced glycogen synthesis in the liver: Glycogen synthesis is not enhanced in T1DM due to the lack of insulin. Instead, glycogen breakdown is increased to release glucose, worsening hyperglycemia.
  • • Option C. Enhanced glycogen synthesis in the liver:
  • • Option D. Decreased production of ketone bodies: This statement is false; ketone body production is increased in T1DM due to enhanced fatty acid oxidation and accumulation of acetyl CoA, leading to ketosis.
  • • Option D. Decreased production of ketone bodies:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus, insulin deficiency promotes increased fat mobilization from adipose tissue, leading to elevated free fatty acids that are converted into ketone bodies by the liver. The lack of insulin prevents proper glucose utilization, driving the body to use fats for energy, resulting in ketosis and ketoacidosis. Understanding these metabolic shifts is critical in managing and preventing complications associated with diabetic ketoacidosis.

questions.text: Organize the subsequent afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle, proceeding from the medial to the lateral direction. (INICET MAY 2023) 1. General somatic 2. General visceral 3. Special somatic 4. Special visceral

  • • Eccrine glands are involved in thermoregulation and are not associated with hair follicles. They produce a watery sweat that is not typically odorous.
  • • thermoregulation

  • • Option B. Face :
  • • Option B. Face
  • • While there are some apocrine glands on the face, they are not as numerous or as active as those in the axilla. The face primarily contains sebaceous glands and eccrine sweat glands .
  • • While there are some apocrine glands on the face, they are not as numerous or as active as those in the axilla.
  • • The face primarily contains sebaceous glands and eccrine sweat glands .
  • • sebaceous glands
  • • eccrine sweat glands
  • • Option D. Scalp :
  • • Option D. Scalp
  • • The scalp does have apocrine glands, but they are far less concentrated and active compared to those in the axilla. The scalp also contains eccrine sweat glands and is rich in sebaceous glands.
  • • The scalp does have apocrine glands, but they are far less concentrated and active compared to those in the axilla.
  • • The scalp also contains eccrine sweat glands and is rich in sebaceous glands.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Identify the axilla as the primary location of apocrine sweat glands.

questions.explanation:

Additionally, wearing a face mask in situations necessitating public outings remains crucial.

  • ➤ RUBELLA
  • ➤ RUBELLA

  • ➤ IP → 14-21 Days
  • ➤ Source → Cases [No carriers - No Iceberg phenomenon]
  • ➤ Mode of Transmission → Resp. [Air droplets]

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presented with sudden-onset blindness for the past 4 hours. However, on history taking, it is noted that she is not concerned about it. However, she is concerned that her mother passed away recently and that she should have spent more time with her. Physical examination findings are normal. Which of the following is true about the condition? (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: In adults, equally among males and females

options.label: C
options.text: In adults, occurs more in males than in females

options.label: D
options.text: In children, occurs more in females than in males

questions.correct_answer: D. In children, occurs more in females than in males
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) In children, occurs more in females than in males

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Conversion disorder , also known as dissociative neurological symptom disorder , is characterized by neurological symptoms that can't be explained by a medical condition and are believed to arise in response to psychological stressors. The symptoms do not conform with anatomical and physiological principles . The condition is more common in females in both pediatric and adult populations.
  • ➤ Conversion disorder
  • ➤ dissociative neurological symptom disorder
  • ➤ do not conform
  • ➤ anatomical
  • ➤ physiological principles
  • ➤ more common in females

CT Scan showed a well-defined mass in the orbit with an irregular border and adjacent bony destruction. Biopsy showed small, round cells which were positive for Desmin in Immunohistochemistry. What is the probable diagnosis? ( AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the structure marked by red arrow in the image below? ( AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Trochlear nerve

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The structure marked in the image is the superior oblique muscle. It is innervated by the trochlear nerve.
  • • There are seven extraocular muscles present in the eye. They are:
  • • Levator palpebrae superioris - Which elevates the upper eyelids Four recti muscles - Superior, inferior, medial, and lateral recti Two obliques - Superior and inferior oblique
  • • Levator palpebrae superioris - Which elevates the upper eyelids
  • • Four recti muscles - Superior, inferior, medial, and lateral recti
  • • Two obliques - Superior and inferior oblique
  • • The muscles originate from the back of the orbit in a common tendinous ring called the annulus of Zinn and are inserted into the sclera.
  • • All the extraocular muscles are innervated by the oculomotor (III) except Superior Oblique (Trochlear nerve, IV) and Lateral rectus (Abducens, VI)
  • • All the extraocular muscles are innervated by the oculomotor (III) except Superior Oblique (Trochlear nerve, IV) and Lateral rectus (Abducens, VI)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Oculomotor nerve: This nerve innervates most of the extraocular muscles except for the superior oblique and the lateral rectus. It does not innervate the structure marked in the image, which is the superior oblique muscle.
  • • Option A. Oculomotor nerve:
  • • Option C. Trigeminal nerve: This nerve primarily provides sensory innervation to the face and does not innervate any of the extraocular muscles, including the superior oblique.
  • • Option C. Trigeminal nerve:
  • • Option D. Abducens nerve: This nerve innervates the lateral rectus muscle only, which abducts the eye. It does not innervate the superior oblique muscle.
  • • Option D. Abducens nerve:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The superior oblique muscle, is uniquely innervated by the trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV), which is the only cranial nerve that exits the brainstem dorsally. This muscle functions to depress, abduct, and internally rotate the eyeball, and it is the only extraocular muscle innervated by the trochlear nerve. Remembering this specific innervation is crucial for diagnosing and managing ocular motility disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following are true regarding KF ring? (INICET NOV 2020) 1. Seen in all patients with neurological involvement 2. Is pathognomonic for Wilson's disease 3. Resolves with desferrioxamine 4. Seen in all patients with hepatic involvement 5. Seen in superior and inferior pole of Descemet's membrane
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1 and 5 only.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ KF can be seen in disorders causing chronic cholestasis. Seen in ~99% of patients with neuro wilson's, 44-60% with hepatic involvement.
  • ➤ Desferioxamine is chelating agent in iron toxicity.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Liver/Wilsons/Chap 344

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency room after consuming 8 digoxin tablets. On examination, he was found to be unstable, with a heart rate of 56 beats per minute. An ECG revealed a third-degree heart block. What is the next step in this patient's care? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Digoxin Immune Fab

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The administration of Digoxin Immune Fab is the next step in the management of life-threatening digoxin toxicity, particularly in the presence of bradycardia and third-degree heart block.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male individual arrived at the emergency room following a road traffic accident, displaying signs indicative of a potential pelvic fracture. Upon assessment, he was determined to be experiencing hypovolemic shock. What is the initial course of action for managing hemorrhage control in this scenario? ( INICET MAY 2023)

options.label: C
options.text: Use bedsheets to compress the pelvis

questions.correct_answer: C. Use bedsheets to compress the pelvis
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Use bedsheets to compress the pelvis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Given the acute nature of the presentation and the need for immediate action to address life-threatening bleeding, the primary and fastest step would be C) Use bedsheets to compress the pelvis . This is a temporizing measure that can stabilize the patient until more definitive interventions (like external or internal fixation) can be safely undertaken.
  • ➤ C) Use bedsheets to
  • ➤ compress the pelvis

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to the clinic with fatigue, pallor, and numbness in his extremities. Laboratory results indicate macrocytic anemia and elevated homocysteine levels, suggesting a deficiency in vitamin B12. Which of the following enzymes is dependent on vitamin B12 for its function, thereby explaining the patient’s symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Methylmalonyl CoA Mutase is a vitamin B12-dependent enzyme that converts methylmalonyl CoA to succinyl CoA, a crucial step in the catabolism of certain amino acids and fatty acids. In vitamin B12 deficiency, methylmalonyl CoA accumulates, leading to the formation of methylmalonic acid, which contributes to the neurological symptoms and metabolic disturbances observed in the patient.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Dihydrofolate Reductase: This enzyme reduces dihydrofolate (DHF) to tetrahydrofolate (THF) and is essential in folate metabolism but does not require vitamin B12 for its activity.
  • • Option B. Dihydrofolate Reductase:
  • • Option C. Thymidylate Synthase: Thymidylate Synthase catalyzes the conversion of deoxyuridine monophosphate (dUMP) to deoxythymidine monophosphate (dTMP), a critical step in DNA synthesis, but it is folate-dependent rather than B12-dependent.
  • • Option C. Thymidylate Synthase:
  • • Option D. Methionine Adenosyltransferase: This enzyme catalyzes the formation of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) from methionine but does not directly depend on vitamin B12 for its function.
  • • Option D. Methionine Adenosyltransferase:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin B12 is essential for the functioning of specific enzymes like methyl malonyl CoA mutase and methionine synthase, both of which play critical roles in amino acid metabolism and methylation processes. Deficiency of B12 leads to metabolic disturbances manifesting as neurological symptoms and hematological abnormalities, highlighting the importance of these enzymes in maintaining normal physiological functions.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most effective oral drug in smoking cessation? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Varenicline

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Varenicline is the most effective oral medication for smoking cessation due to its unique mechanism of partially stimulating and blocking nicotine receptors, thereby reducing cravings and the satisfaction derived from smoking. Other drugs like cevimeline, muscarine, and atropine do not have the same efficacy or mechanism for aiding in smoking cessation.

questions.text: All of the following statements are false about IL-12 except? (INICET NOV 2022) Increases production of interferon- γ Inhibits T cells Inhibits B cells Produced by macrophages
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1 and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Interleukin-12 (IL-12) is produced by macrophages and increases the production of interferon- γ (IFN- γ).

questions.text: A married woman gives birth to twins. The husband doubts he is the father and gets a paternity test done. The test shows that he is the father of one infant but not the other. This is? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A case of superfecundation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Superfecundation:
  • • Superfecundation:
  • • This refers to the fertilization of two ova in the same menstrual cycle by sperm from different acts of intercourse, potentially involving different partners. This scenario explains how twins can have different fathers, as one ovum could be fertilized by sperm from the husband, and the other by sperm from another man.
  • • This refers to the fertilization of two ova in the same menstrual cycle by sperm from different acts of intercourse, potentially involving different partners.
  • • This scenario explains how twins can have different fathers, as one ovum could be fertilized by sperm from the husband, and the other by sperm from another man.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Superfetation: This refers to fertilization of two ova from different menstrual cycles. It is an extremely rare phenomenon and has never been documented in humans, though it is known to occur in some animals.
  • • Option A. Superfetation:
  • • Option B. One infant is atavistic: Atavism refers to the appearance of characteristics found in distant ancestors but not observed in recent generations. It does not apply to paternity.
  • • Option B. One infant is atavistic:
  • • Option D. One infant is suppositious : Suppositious refers to something that is fraudulently substituted. This term does not explain the situation of having different fathers for twins.
  • • Option D. One infant is suppositious

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Superfecundation is the fertilization of two ova in the same menstrual cycle by sperm from different partners, explaining how twins can have different fathers.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 2188, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 2188, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A-1, B-5, C-3, D-2, E-4

questions.text: The strict anaerobe among the following is: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Prevotella

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prevotella species are strict anaerobes, thriving in oxygen-free environments, and are part of the normal flora of the oral, vaginal, and gut microbiota. They can be involved in various anaerobic infections, particularly of the respiratory tract.

questions.text: Myosin head detaches from actin by which of the following mechanism? ( AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Binding of ATP

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The detachment of the myosin head from actin is caused by the binding of ATP to the myosin head, which is a critical step in the muscle contraction and relaxation cycle.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic with fatigue, dizziness, and recent weight loss. She mentions that she has been following a very restrictive diet for the past two weeks, consuming very few calories each day. On physical examination, she appears slightly dehydrated, with sunken eyes and dry mucous membranes. Blood glucose levels are normal, but a dipstick urine test reveals the presence of ketone bodies. Which urine test is most commonly used to detect ketone bodies in a starvation state?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Rothera’s test is the standard test used to detect ketone bodies in urine, which commonly appear during states of increased ketogenesis such as starvation, prolonged fasting, or uncontrolled diabetes. The test involves adding sodium nitroprusside and ammonium sulfate to the urine sample; the formation of a purple ring indicates the presence of acetoacetate and acetone, two key ketone bodies. Ketone bodies are produced when fatty acids are broken down for energy due to insufficient carbohydrate intake, leading to ketonuria, which is often seen in starvation, ketogenic diets, or diabetic ketoacidosis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Benedict’s test: Benedict's test detects reducing sugars in urine, such as glucose, fructose, and lactose. It is commonly used in the diagnosis of conditions like diabetes mellitus but does not detect ketone bodies.
  • • Option A. Benedict’s test:
  • • Option B. Heat coagulation test: The heat coagulation test is used to detect the presence of proteins in urine. When the urine is heated, proteins precipitate, forming a cloudy appearance, which is seen in conditions such as nephrotic syndrome or other kidney disorders. It is not used for ketone body detection.
  • • Option B. Heat coagulation test:
  • • Option D. Sulfosalicylic acid test: This test is used to detect proteins in the urine by causing protein precipitation, indicating proteinuria. It is not useful in identifying ketone bodies, making it irrelevant for detecting ketosis or ketonuria.
  • • Option D. Sulfosalicylic acid test:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rothera’s test is specifically used to detect ketone bodies in the urine, which are commonly present in conditions such as starvation, prolonged fasting, and diabetic ketoacidosis. Understanding this test helps identify metabolic states that induce ketogenesis, aiding in the appropriate management of patients with these conditions.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient, during his routine annual checkup, is found to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 40 mm in diameter on USG abdomen. Which of the following is true about the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2020)

options.label: B
options.text: Surgery is indicated if aneurysmal diameter is >55mm

options.label: C
options.text: Urgently wheel the patient to OT for surgery

options.label: D
options.text: Surgery is indicated only if aneurysm is > 70mm

questions.correct_answer: B. Surgery is indicated if aneurysmal diameter is >55mm
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Surgery is indicated if aneurysmal diameter is >55mm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Surgery (open surgical repair or EVAR) is recommended for asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysms when the diameter reaches 55mm or greater due to the increased risk of rupture beyond this size. Regular monitoring is advised for smaller aneurysms.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient is diagnosed with pure red cell aplasia and a mediastinal mass. Which of the following can be the likely cause? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Thymoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thymoma is the most likely cause of a mediastinal mass in a patient with pure red cell aplasia. PRCA is characterized by a selective deficiency of erythroid precursors in the bone marrow, leading to severe anemia with normal granulocyte and platelet counts, and is often associated with thymoma.

questions.text: Which gene is not involved in double strand DNA break repair mechanism? ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ understand the roles of different genes and proteins in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks (DSBs), which is essential for maintaining genome stability and preventing mutations.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to a tertiary care hospital in India with a history of fatigue, unexplained weight loss, and persistent cough for the last six months. He has a 20-pack-year smoking history but quit five years ago. Physical examination reveals pallor and mild hepatomegaly. Laboratory investigations, including complete blood count, show anemia. A biopsy of a liver lesion is performed, revealing evidence of abnormal gene expression regulation, particularly in genes involved in cellular proliferation and apoptosis. The pathologist explains that these changes are not due to mutations in the DNA sequence but rather alterations in gene accessibility and chromatin structure. Which of the following processes is most likely responsible for this abnormal gene regulation?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • DNA methylation is a key epigenetic modification involving the addition of methyl groups to cytosine residues in DNA, typically leading to suppression of gene activity by condensing the chromatin and restricting access to transcription factors. In the clinical scenario, the description of altered gene expression without direct mutations aligns with epigenetic changes like DNA methylation, which commonly leads to reduced gene expression by silencing gene promoters.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Histone acetylation: This process involves the addition of acetyl groups to histones, leading to a relaxed chromatin state and increased gene expression, which is the opposite effect seen in the patient’s case.
  • • Option
  • • A) Histone acetylation:
  • • Option C) Point mutation: This involves direct alterations in the DNA sequence itself, unlike the described epigenetic modifications that do not change the DNA sequence but rather affect gene expression indirectly.
  • • Option
  • • C) Point mutation:
  • • Option D) Gene duplication: This process involves an increase in the number of gene copies, which could lead to increased gene expression, but it does not match the mechanism of epigenetic regulation described in the scenario.
  • • Option
  • • D) Gene duplication:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Epigenetic modifications such as DNA methylation and histone acetylation regulate gene expression without altering the DNA sequence. DNA methylation typically suppresses gene expression, whereas histone acetylation enhances it by modifying chromatin accessibility. These modifications can be influenced by environmental factors and contribute to disease development without direct genetic mutations.

questions.text: Glucose is stored in the form of glycogen because? ( INICET May 2020)

options.label: C
options.text: It can be stored at multiple organs

options.label: D
options.text: It can provide glucose for about 1 week when needed

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) It is compact

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glycogen is stored in a compact form, allowing efficient storage of large amounts of glucose in liver and muscle cells, enabling rapid mobilization of glucose when needed.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamin needs to be supplied in the diet of patients with Cystathionine beta synthase defect? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cysteine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cystathionine beta synthase (CBS) is involved in the synthesis of cysteine from dietary methionine. Cysteine synthesis require methionine, serine and vitamin B6. The reactions are summarized in the diagram:
  • ➤ So, in case of CBS deficiency there will be no formation of cystathionine and cysteine. so, cysteine becomes essential and needs to be taken in diet.
  • ➤ Ref -Harper 31 st e/pg. 291
  • ➤ Ref -Harper 31 st e/pg. 291

questions.text: A couple with 2 children who are not able to conceive for over an year now present to the OPD. The male partner is diagnosed to be having hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism. Which of the following is not true? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Low prolactin levels

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism in males is characterized by a deficiency of gonadotropins (LH and FSH), which leads to low testosterone levels and impaired spermatogenesis. This condition often results in oligospermia or azoospermia, contributing to infertility. Additionally, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is frequently associated with hyperprolactinemia rather than low prolactin levels.
  • • Low LH and FSH: Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is marked by low levels of luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) due to inadequate secretion from the pituitary gland. Low testosterone: The low levels of LH lead to reduced stimulation of Leydig cells in the testes, resulting in low testosterone levels. Oligospermia: The low levels of FSH result in impaired spermatogenesis, often leading to oligospermia or azoospermia. Low prolactin levels (Incorrect): Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is associated with hyperprolactinemia, not low prolactin levels. Elevated prolactin can inhibit the secretion of gonadotropins, further exacerbating the condition.
  • • Low LH and FSH: Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is marked by low levels of luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) due to inadequate secretion from the pituitary gland.
  • • Low LH and FSH:
  • • Low testosterone: The low levels of LH lead to reduced stimulation of Leydig cells in the testes, resulting in low testosterone levels.
  • • Low testosterone:
  • • Oligospermia: The low levels of FSH result in impaired spermatogenesis, often leading to oligospermia or azoospermia.
  • • Oligospermia:
  • • Low prolactin levels (Incorrect): Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is associated with hyperprolactinemia, not low prolactin levels. Elevated prolactin can inhibit the secretion of gonadotropins, further exacerbating the condition.
  • • Low prolactin levels (Incorrect):
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Low LH and FSH: True. Gonadotropin deficiency is a hallmark of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.
  • • Option A. Low LH and FSH:
  • • Option B. Low testosterone: True. The deficiency in LH leads to low testosterone production.
  • • Option B. Low testosterone:
  • • Option C. Oligospermia: True. The deficiency in FSH leads to impaired spermatogenesis, causing oligospermia or azoospermia.
  • • Option C. Oligospermia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A male with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism will have high prolactin levels, low gonadotropins (LH and FSH), low testosterone, and often oligospermia or azoospermia.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 199, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 199, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 8 th edition

questions.text: A 33-year-old female patient comes with complaints of menorrhagia for the past 3 months. The duration and regularity of her menstrual cycles are normal. Non- hormonal management has been tried without success. What is the most appropriate next step? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hormonal therapy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Hormonal therapy is the next best management modality for menorrhagia when non-hormonal management has failed. This includes combined oral contraceptive pills or even progesterone-only devices like the LND-IUS. First-line management includes non-hormonal treatment like NSAIDs and Tranexamic acid.
  • • Hormonal therapy is the next best management modality for menorrhagia when non-hormonal management has failed. This includes combined oral contraceptive pills or even progesterone-only devices like the LND-IUS.
  • • First-line management includes non-hormonal treatment like NSAIDs and Tranexamic acid.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. Uterine artery embolization : Uterine artery embolization is a surgical option and is considered when other treatments fail.
  • • Option A. Uterine artery embolization
  • • Option B. Endometrial ablation : Endometrial ablation is also a surgical option and should be considered after hormonal therapy.
  • • Option B. Endometrial ablation
  • • Option D. Hysterectomy : Hysterectomy is the last resort and is used when all other management options fail or are contraindicated.
  • • Option D. Hysterectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Hormonal therapy, including combined oral contraceptive pills or progesterone-only devices like the LND-IUS, is the next best management step for menorrhagia when non-hormonal management has been ineffective.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 197, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 197, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6 th edition

questions.text: An 18-month-old baby presents with vesicles on the anterior abdominal wall and forearm, as well as meningitis. A Tzanck smear shows multinucleated giant cells. The mother has a history of genital lesions. What is the likely diagnosis, and what is the causative agent? ( INICET May 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) HSV 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HSV-2 is a common cause of neonatal herpes, which presents with vesicular lesions and can be confirmed with a Tzanck smear showing multinucleate giant cells. Maternal genital herpes is a significant risk factor for neonatal transmission.
